asgn2Manifests

Class CargoManifest

  • java.lang.Object
    • asgn2Manifests.CargoManifest

  • public class CargoManifest
extends java.lang.Object
    A class for managing a container ship's cargo manifest. It allows freight containers of various types to be loaded and unloaded, within various constraints.

    In particular, the ship's captain has set the following rules for loading of new containers:

    1. New containers may be loaded only if doing so does not exceed the ship's weight limit.
    2. New containers are to be loaded as close to the bridge as possible. (Stack number zero is nearest the bridge.)
    3. A new container may be added to a stack only if doing so will not exceed the maximum allowed stack height.
    4. A new container may be loaded only if a container with the same code is not already on board.
    5. Stacks of containers must be homogeneous, i.e., each stack must consist of containers of one type (general, refrigerated or dangerous goods) only.

    Furthermore, since the containers are moved by an overhead crane, a container can be unloaded only if it is on top of a stack.

    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    CAB302

    • Constructor Detail

      • CargoManifest

        public CargoManifest(java.lang.Integer numStacks,
                     java.lang.Integer maxHeight,
                     java.lang.Integer maxWeight)
              throws ManifestException
        Constructs a new cargo manifest in preparation for a voyage. When a cargo manifest is constructed the specific cargo parameters for the voyage are set, including the number of stack spaces available on the deck (which depends on the deck configuration for the voyage), the maximum allowed height of any stack (which depends on the weather conditions expected for the voyage), and the total weight of containers allowed onboard (which depends on the amount of ballast and fuel being carried).
        Parameters:
        numStacks - the number of stacks that can be accommodated on deck
        maxHeight - the maximum allowable height of any stack
        maxWeight - the maximum weight of containers allowed on board (in tonnes)
        Throws:
        ManifestException - if negative numbers are given for any of the parameters

    • Method Detail

      • loadContainer

        public void loadContainer(FreightContainer newContainer)
                   throws ManifestException
        Loads a freight container onto the ship, provided that it can be accommodated within the five rules set by the captain.
        Parameters:
        newContainer - the new freight container to be loaded
        Throws:
        ManifestException - if adding this container would exceed the ship's weight limit; if a container with the same code is already on board; or if no suitable space can be found for this container

      • unloadContainer

        public void unloadContainer(ContainerCode containerId)
                     throws ManifestException
        Unloads a particular container from the ship, provided that it is accessible (i.e., on top of a stack).
        Parameters:
        containerId - the code of the container to be unloaded
        Throws:
        ManifestException - if the container is not accessible because it's not on the top of a stack (including the case where it's not on board the ship at all)

      • whichStack

        public java.lang.Integer whichStack(ContainerCode queryContainer)
        Returns which stack holds a particular container, if any. The container of interest is identified by its unique code. Constant null is returned if the container is not on board.
        Parameters:
        queryContainer - the container code for the container of interest
        Returns:
        the number of the stack with the container in it, or null if the container is not on board

      • howHigh

        public java.lang.Integer howHigh(ContainerCode queryContainer)
        Returns how high in its stack a particular container is. The container of interest is identified by its unique code. Height is measured in the number of containers, counting from zero. Thus the container at the bottom of a stack is at "height" 0, the container above it is at height 1, and so on. Constant null is returned if the container is not on board.
        Parameters:
        queryContainer - the container code for the container of interest
        Returns:
        the container's height in the stack, or null if the container is not on board

      • toArray

        public FreightContainer[] toArray(java.lang.Integer stackNo)
                           throws ManifestException
        Returns the contents of a particular stack as an array, starting with the bottommost container at position zero in the array.
        Parameters:
        stackNo - the number of the stack of interest
        Returns:
        the stack's freight containers as an array
        Throws:
        ManifestException - if there is no such stack on the ship

        public java.lang.String toString(ContainerCode toFind)
